Title:
Species of Lasiodiplodia associated with papaya stem-end rot
in Brazil
Keywords:
Botryosphaeriaceae, Carica papaya, Fruit rot, EF1-Î±, ITS,
Phylogeny, Virulence
Abstract:
This study aims to identify and characterize species of
Lasiodiplodia associated with stem-end rot of papaya in six different
populations in the Northeast of Brazil. Fungal identifications were made
using a combination of morphology together with a phylogenetic analysis
based on partial translation elongation factor 1-Î± sequence (EF-1Î±)
and internal transcribed spacers (ITS). Five species of Lasiodiplodia
were identified: Lasiodiplodia brasiliense sp. nov., L. hormozganensis,
L. marypalme sp. nov., L. pseudotheobromae and L. theobromae. Only L.
theobromae had previously been reported in papaya, while all the other
species are reported for the first time in association with this host in
Brazil and worldwide. Lasiodiplodia theobromae was the most prevalent
species. All species of Lasiodiplodia were pathogenic on papaya fruit,
with L. hormozganensis being the most virulent.
